document.docAuthor: Garrison, Rosser W. & Ellenrieder, Natalia Von
document.masterDocTitle: Damselflies of the genus Argia (Odonata: Coenagrionidae) from Ecuador with descriptions of five new species

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Argia cuprea
Form b:
Ris 1918: 110
, 112, 113 (key, notes, mention female from Songo River as possibly representing
A. dives
).

Remarks: This is one of the two
cuprea
-like metallic red species known from South America (but see under
A. fulgida
). It is closely related to
A. philipi
and it is treated and diagnosed under that species. Although
Argia cuprea
has been recorded as occurring in South America (e. g. Pérez-Gutiérrez & Palacino-Rodriquez 2011, Amaya- Perilla & Palacino-Rodriguez 2012), this species has not been collected south of Panama ( Garrison & von Ellenrieder 2017 ). We have been unable to examine Ris' examples of
Argia cuprea
Form b but his illustration of the dorsal view of the cerci ( Fig. 134 ) of a male from Villavicencio, Colombia strongly suggest that his specimens represent
A. dives
. In dorsal view, the outer margin of cercus in
A. dives
is about as long as the inner margin ( Figs. 107a, 108a ); in
A. philipi
, the outer margin of the cercus is clearly shorter than the inner margin ( Fig. 119b ). Ris (1918) mentioned the possibility that at least one of his specimens might represent
A. dives
("Das ♀ vom Rio Songo ist erhebIich grosser, stimmt aber sonst völlig überein, was natürlich nicht ausschliesst, dass dazu ein etwas verschiedenes ♂ gehören könnte. Abd. 32, Hfl. 26. Vielleicht ist es der Form zuzurechnen, die Förster (Arch f. Naturgesch. 1914, A, 2, p. 61) nach 1 ♂ vom Vulkan Vilcanota in Peru als
A. cuprea dives
beschreibt." [The female from Songo River is considerably larger, however it agrees otherwise entirely, which of course does not leave out the possibility that it could belong to a somewhat different male. Abd 32, HW 26. Maybe this form belongs to what Förster (Arch. f. Naturgesch. 1914) described as
A. cuprea dives
from 1 ♂ from volcano Vilcanota in Peru .]). Fraser (1946) further complicated matters by including
A. cupraurea
(as forma d) and
Argia cuprea
forma a and b of Ris under his synonymy for
A. cuprea
and describing and illustrating ( Figs. 1 , f & g) a new form,
Argia cuprea
Forma c, as new from San Antonio, Peru . These are treated under
A. limitata
.
